content: The Act titled "Fixing the Federal Voting Assistance Program Act of 2008" appoints and outlines qualifications for the Presidential designee. The Act "Fixing the Federal Voting Assistance Program Act of 2008" appoints a Presidential designee for federal functions related to absentee voting, requiring prior experience in election administration. The Act appoints a Presidential designee for federal functions related to absentee voting, allowing the current designee to continue without meeting appointment and qualifications requirements for 6 months after the enactment of the Act. The Overseas Voting Advisory Board is established under Section 3 of the Act. The Overseas Voting Advisory Board is established to conduct studies and issue reports on voter registration and voting methods for US citizens residing outside the country. The Overseas Voting Advisory Board is tasked with evaluating the administration and enforcement of the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act, as well as identifying the need for legislation or administrative actions to ensure all eligible Americans living overseas or serving in the military can register and vote in elections. The Board must submit an annual report to Congress by March 31 detailing its activities. The Overseas Voting Advisory Board evaluates the implementation of the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act and makes recommendations for legislative or administrative actions to improve voting access for eligible Americans abroad or in the military. Congress holds hearings on the Board's annual report to discuss potential funding and solutions for the issues identified. The provisions of subparagraph (A) are enacted as part of the rules of the House or Senate, superseding any inconsistent rules, with the recognition of the constitutional right of either House to change such rules relating to procedure at any time. The Board shall consist of 5 members appointed by the President within 6 months of the Act's enactment, with nominees submitted by the Speaker of the House, Minority Leader of the House, Majority Leader of the Senate, and Minority Leader of the Senate. The Board consists of 5 members appointed by the President within 6 months of the Act's enactment, with nominees submitted by the Minority Leader of the Senate. Members must have experience in election administration and reside overseas for an extended period. Each member serves a 4-year term and vacancies are filled accordingly. Members appointed to fill vacancies serve for the remainder of the predecessor's term and may continue until a successor is in place. They serve without pay but receive travel expenses as per applicable regulations. The Chairperson can request reimbursement of travel expenses from a presidential designee. The Board members can be reimbursed for travel expenses by the Presidential designee under the Uniformed and Overseas Citizens Absentee Voting Act. A quorum consists of 3 members, and the Board designates one member as Chairperson. The Chairperson has the authority to appoint staff as necessary. The staff of the Board is appointed under civil service laws, paid according to specific provisions, and experts can be hired as needed. Federal agencies can provide personnel to assist the Board upon request. The Board has powers to hold hearings, obtain official data from government agencies, use the United States mails, and request administrative support services. The Board can request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services on a reimbursable basis to carry out its responsibilities. Appropriations are authorized for the Board to fulfill its duties each fiscal year.
